Improving Semi-supervised Federated Learning by Reducing the Gradient Diversity of Models

Zhengming Zhang1111equal contribution ,Yaoqing Yang2\samethanks, Zhewei Yao2\samethanks , Yujun Yan3,
Joseph E. Gonzalez2, Michael W. Mahoney2,4
1 Southeast University
2 University of California, Berkeley
3 University of Michigan, Ann Arbor
4 International Computer Science Institute

Improving Semi-supervised Federated Learning by Reducing the Gradient Diversity of Models

Zhengming Zhang1111equal contribution ,Yaoqing Yang2\samethanks, Zhewei Yao2\samethanks , Yujun Yan3,
Joseph E. Gonzalez2, Michael W. Mahoney2,4
1 Southeast University
2 University of California, Berkeley
3 University of Michigan, Ann Arbor
4 International Computer Science Institute
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a promising way to use the computing power of mobile devices while maintaining the privacy of users. Current work in FL, however, makes the unrealistic assumption that the users have ground-truth labels on their devices, while also assuming that the server has neither data nor labels. In this work, we consider the more realistic scenario where the users have only unlabeled data, while the server has some labeled data, and where the amount of labeled data is smaller than the amount of unlabeled data. We call this learning problem semi-supervised federated learning (SSFL). For SSFL, we demonstrate that a critical issue that affects the test accuracy is the large gradient diversity of the models from different users. Based on this, we investigate several design choices. First, we find that the so-called consistency regularization loss (CRL), which is widely used in semi-supervised learning, performs reasonably well but has large gradient diversity. Second, we find that Batch Normalization (BN) increases gradient diversity. Replacing BN with the recently-proposed Group Normalization (GN) can reduce gradient diversity and improve test accuracy. Third, we show that CRL combined with GN still has a large gradient diversity when the number of users is large. Based on these results, we propose a novel grouping-based model averaging method to replace the FedAvg averaging method. Overall, our grouping-based averaging, combined with GN and CRL, achieves better test accuracy than not just a contemporary paper on SSFL in the same settings (>10%), but also four supervised FL algorithms.

1 Introduction

State-of-the-art machine learning models can benefit from the large amount of user data privately held on mobile devices, as well as the computing power locally available on these devices. In response to this, federated learning (FL) has been proposed [1, 2]. In a typical FL pipeline, a server and some users jointly learn a model in multiple rounds. In each round, models are are updated locally (e.g., on users’ devices) based on private user data, the server aggregates the updated models sent from the users, and the server then shares the aggregated model with the users for the next round.

In FL, it is commonly assumed that the data stored on the local devices are fully annotated with ground-truth labels, and that the server does not have any labeled data [1, 2, 3]. However, this assumption does not hold in practice. On the one hand, there is not a sufficient supply of labeled data on the users’ side [4], as labeling data requires both time and domain knowledge [5, 6]. On the other hand, the server, which is often hosted by organizations, is more likely than a single user to acquire labeled data. To give some concrete examples, consider two scenarios: cross-device FL (in which users are mobile devices) and cross-silo FL (in which users are organizations) [7]. In a cross-device scenario, where a central server trains an object detector on images with the help of mobile users, the server can use a public dataset, e.g., [8], to obtain labels, while the users often do not have images with ground-truth bounding boxes. In a cross-silo scenario, where multiple medical institutes work together to diagnose a disease, the disease may be newly discovered by one medical institute, and so no labeled samples are present at other institutes [4].222There is some nuance here that the medical institute with ground-truth labels is physically different from the server, and the server itself does not have data. However, it will become apparent that this nuance does not affect the mathematical formulation considered in our paper because we can assume (virtually) that the server and the institute with labels are co-located and work together as a new server. In these scenarios, the typical supervised FL setting is not appropriate.

Motivated by these practical scenarios, we study the semi-supervised federated learning (SSFL) setting. In SSFL, users only have access to unlabeled data, while the server only has a small amount of labeled data.333In addition to our main setup, when users have unlabeled data only, we also compare our method to the state-of-the-art in another “label-at-client” scenario [9], when users have a limited amount of labeled data. Our method outperforms [9] in this new scenario by a large margin (¿10%). The goal is to train a model that can benefit from both labeled and unlabeled data. In this context, our main contributions are the following.

  1. 1.

    Demonstrating the importance of “gradient diversity.” We demonstrate the importance of reducing the gradient diversity [10], a notion which captures the dissimilarity between local gradient updates of users, in SSFL. First, we show that the consistency regularization loss (CRL) [11] can achieve reasonably good test accuracy, but it still has significantly larger gradient diversity than supervised FL. Then, we show that replacing the batch normalization (BN) [12] in the model with group normalization (GN) [13] can reduce gradient diversity and enhance test accuracy in the SSFL setting. Finally, we propose a grouping-based model averaging technique to replace FedAvg [2], to reduce gradient diversity further and to increase accuracy, especially when there are a large number of users.

  2. 2.

    Proposing a strong baseline. By proposing solutions to reduce gradient diversity, we obtain a strong SSFL approach. Our method outperforms another SSFL approach from a contemporary paper [9] in the same settings by 14.79%-18.10% in test accuracy. Our method also achieves comparable or better accuracy than four existing supervised FL approaches that do not use GN or the grouping-based averaging. Specifically, our approach is 0.80%/0.29% better than EASGD/OverlapSGD [14, 15], despite having a lower communication frequency, and our approach is 14.44%/11.14% better than FedAvg/DataSharing [2, 16], even when the degree of our non-iidness (in the sense of different distributions of classes at different users) is higher.

  3. 3.

    Extensive empirical evaluation. We evaluate the proposed solution by varying different environmental factors and testing on multiple datasets. The environmental factors include different levels of non-iidness, the communication period (i.e., the number of local update steps at each user between two communication rounds), the total amount of labeled data in the server, the number of users, and the number of users that communicate with the server in each communication round. Interestingly, the problem of having large gradient diversity when the number of communicating users is large is discovered in one of these empirical evaluations (see Section 4.2).

Overall, by formulating the SSFL problem, analyzing the key limitation of large gradient diversity, selecting different design choices to reduce the gradient diversity, and thoroughly evaluating our design under different environmental factors, we provide a strong baseline for this SSFL setting. This strong baseline can achieve comparable or better accuracy than the state-of-the-art methods in both semi-supervised and supervised FL. The proposed method also only focuses on a few crucial components (e.g., normalization) that are easy to change in practice. To help the FL community reproduce our results, we have open-sourced our code.444https://github.com/jhcknzzm/SSFL-Benchmarking-Semi-supervised-Federated-Learning

2 Semi-supervised federated learning

2.1 Basic setup

In this subsection, we discuss the basic setup of SSFL. There exist a cloud server and K𝐾K users/devices. Similar to the common FL setup [1], the users and the server collaborate to train a model in multiple rounds by exchanging and updating model weights. For each round of communication, we allow the number of participating users connected to the server, which we denote as C𝐶C, to be smaller than K𝐾K, as is done commonly [7]. This is because, for example, some mobile devices only participate in the learning when being charged [7]. Assuming C≤K𝐶𝐾C\leq K for each round of communication can simulate this drop-and-reconnect case.

We denote the labeled dataset at the server as Ds={(xi,yi)}i=1Nssubscript𝐷𝑠superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑠{D_{s}}{\rm{=}}\left\{{\left({{x_{i}},{y_{i}}}\right)}\right\}_{i=1}^{{N_{s}}}, and the unlabeled dataset stored at the k𝑘k-th user as Dk={xi}i=1Nksubscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑘{D_{k}}{\rm{=}}\left\{{{x_{i}}}\right\}_{i=1}^{{N_{k}}}, for k∈{1,…,Kk\in\{1,\ldots,K}. Here, Nssubscript𝑁𝑠N_{s} (Nksubscript𝑁𝑘N_{k}) is the number of labeled (unlabeled) samples available at the server (k𝑘k-th user). Also, similar to the standard FL setup, no raw data are exchanged between the server and the users. That is to say, the server can only use the dataset Dssubscript𝐷𝑠D_{s}, and the k𝑘k-th user can only use the local dataset Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}. Note that the data distributions at different users are non-iid [16, 17]. In this work, we consider image classification as a representative SSFL task.

We now describe the SSFL training pipeline which can be slightly different from the standard FL setup. Denote the local weights at the k𝑘k-th user as wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k}. Since the server has its own dataset Dssubscript𝐷𝑠D_{s}, unlike the standard FL setup, it also updates its own weights wssubscript𝑤𝑠w_{s}. Denote the averaged weights at the server as wa​v​gsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔w_{avg} (which is different from wssubscript𝑤𝑠w_{s}). At round t𝑡t, the server sends the averaged model weights wa​v​gtsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑡w_{avg}^{t} to the users. Each user, upon receiving wa​v​gtsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑡w_{avg}^{t}, locally updates its own model weights to wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} and transmits wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} to the server. At the same time, the server also has to update its own model weights from wa​v​gtsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑡w_{avg}^{t} to wstsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑠𝑡w_{s}^{t} using the labeled dataset Dssubscript𝐷𝑠D_{s}. Then, the server computes an averaged model wa​v​gt+1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑡1w_{avg}^{t+1} using all the received models, including its own model wstsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑠𝑡w_{s}^{t}. Finally, it proceeds to the next round and sends wa​v​gt+1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑡1w_{avg}^{t+1} to the users. Our basic SSFL setup is illustrated in Fig. 1.

2.2 Gradient diversity, and the ways to reduce it

In this subsection, we present the definition of gradient diversity from [10]. Then, we motivate several design choices to reduce gradient diversity in SSFL. As we have discussed in the introduction, reducing the gradient diversity value is crucial for SSFL.

Definition 1 (Metric for gradient diversity).

The gradient diversity is defined as:

Δt​(w)=∑k∈𝒞t‖∇wkt‖22/‖∑k∈𝒞t∇wkt‖22,superscriptΔ𝑡𝑤subscript𝑘subscript𝒞𝑡superscriptsubscriptnorm∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡22superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑘subscript𝒞𝑡∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡22\small\Delta^{t}(w)=\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{C}_{t}}{\left\|\nabla w_{k}^{t}\right\|_{2}^{2}}/\left\|\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{C}_{t}}\nabla w_{k}^{t}\right\|_{2}^{2}, (1)

where 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t} denotes the set of participating users at round t𝑡t, wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} represents the model weights held by the k𝑘k-th user at the beginning of round t𝑡t, and ∇wkt∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡\nabla w_{k}^{t} represents the gradient of wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} evaluated on all data held by the k𝑘k-th user.

Gradient diversity measures the dissimilarity between the local gradient updates of users. In SSFL, when gradient diversity is too large, the weights from different users are updated towards “different directions,” and it is thus problematic to directly average them, as is done in the common model averaging method known as FedAvg [2]. Gradient diversity gives a quantitative way to study this issue. We only include the users in 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t}, i.e., those who participate in this particular communication round, because only these weights are averaged.

In what follows, we motivate three design choices, which are also shown in  Fig. 1, that can affect gradient diversity.

  1. 1.

    Training objective. Since there are no labels on the users’ side, we have to choose appropriate loss functions carefully when updating local models at the users’ side.

  2. 2.

    Normalization. Normalization (e.g., BN) has become standard in deep neural network models. The SSFL setting requires a careful choice of specific normalization methods.

  3. 3.

    Model averaging. The way the server computes the aggregated model from the models that it receives is also a design choice. We only consider ways to average the model weights, i.e., we do not consider model ensembling or distillation techniques, which can be time-consuming in multiple rounds [18].

2.3 Environmental factors for evaluation

In this subsection, we list some environmental factors that can affect the test accuracy of SSFL algorithms. These factors are not controllable by the designer, and they are independent of the design choices listed in § 2.2. However, these factors are helpful to evaluate different design choices, and they can potentially display the weakness of certain solutions. The following factors are considered.

  1. 1.

    Non-iidness R𝑅R: the non-iid metric of data distributions; see Definition 2.

  2. 2.

    Communication period T𝑇T: during two consecutive communications, the number of gradient update steps locally done by the users and the server.

  3. 3.

    Server data number Nssubscript𝑁𝑠N_{s}: the number of labeled data in the server.

  4. 4.

    User number K𝐾K: the total number of users.

  5. 5.

    Number of participating users C𝐶C: during each communication round, the group of users who send their models to the server.

Varying non-iidness to evaluate our solution. Among the five environmental factors listed above, evaluating with different non-iidness requires special care, because we have to change the dataset to get different degrees of non-iidness. Here, we follow convention and evaluate using synthesized non-iid datasets that have different class distribution skews [15, 16, 17, 19, 20], e.g., a single user can have more data for one class or a couple of classes than others.

To quantify the class distribution skew in our experiments, we use the average total variation distance in Definition 2. In the definition, the empirical class distribution of the data Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} at the k𝑘k-th user is denoted by Pk∈ℝdsubscript𝑃𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑P_{k}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, where d𝑑d is the number of classes. Clearly, ∑j=1dPk​[j]=1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑃𝑘delimited-[]𝑗1\sum_{j=1}^{d}P_{k}[j]=1, for all 1≤k≤K1𝑘𝐾1\leq k\leq K. Recall that K𝐾K is the number of users/devices.

Definition 2 (Metric R𝑅R for non-iid level).

The non-iid metric R𝑅R to measure the class distribution skew is defined as:

R=1K​(K−1)/2​∑1≤k<m≤K‖Pk−Pm‖1/2,𝑅1𝐾𝐾12subscript1𝑘𝑚𝐾subscriptnormsubscript𝑃𝑘subscript𝑃𝑚12\small R=\frac{1}{K(K-1)/2}\sum\nolimits_{1\leq k<m\leq K}\|P_{k}-P_{m}\|_{1}/2, (2)

where ∥⋅∥1\|\cdot\|_{1} is the L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} norm.

Here ‖Pk−Pm‖1/2subscriptnormsubscript𝑃𝑘subscript𝑃𝑚12\|P_{k}-P_{m}\|_{1}/2 is the (normalized) total variation distance, which takes value in [0,1]01[0,1], and K​(K−1)/2𝐾𝐾12K(K-1)/2 is the number of user pairs, i.e., it is the mean total variation distance averaged over pairs of users. In particular, 0≤R≤10𝑅10\leq R\leq 1 [21]. When data are distributed in such a way that each user has a the same empirical class distribution which is uniform Pk=[1/d,…,1/d],∀ksubscript𝑃𝑘1𝑑…1𝑑for-all𝑘P_{k}=[1/d,...,1/d],\forall k, we have R=0𝑅0R=0; and in another extreme, when K=d𝐾𝑑K=d and each user only has samples from one class, we have R=1𝑅1R=1.

Remark 1 (Different data sizes).

The metric R𝑅R in Definition 2 does not explicitly consider the effect of different data sizes Nksubscript𝑁𝑘N_{k}’s at different users. We focus on the case when Nksubscript𝑁𝑘N_{k}’s are equal to each other, while slight difference may arise when the overall number of samples is not divisible by the number of users. Notice that, we consider similar data sizes at different users, but we do not restrict ourselves to the case of uniform class distribution. Specifically, we have tested on datasets with non-uniform class sizes, e.g., SVHN dataset.

We synthesize datasets with a specific R𝑅R value in [0,1]01[0,1] to evaluate our SSFL algorithm. The specific data synthesis and distribution procedures to achieve R𝑅R are relegated to § A.2.

3 Reduce gradient diversity in SSFL

In this section, we study the three SSFL design choices discussed in § 2.2. We first present the details of the choices considered in this paper. Then, we use gradient diversity to analyze them.

3.1 Design choice 1: training objective

In this subsection, we present the training objective and focus on an existing semi-supervised loss called consistency regularization loss (CRL) [11]. In particular, the server loss Lssubscript𝐿𝑠L_{s} and the user loss Lksubscript𝐿𝑘L_{k} (of the k𝑘k-th user) are defined as follows:

Lssubscript𝐿𝑠\displaystyle L_{s} =1Ns​∑(xi,yi)∈Dsl​(yi,fs​(α​(xi);ws)),absent1subscript𝑁𝑠subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝐷𝑠𝑙subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑓𝑠𝛼subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑤𝑠\displaystyle=\frac{1}{N_{s}}\sum\nolimits_{(x_{i},y_{i})\in D_{s}}{l\left({{y_{i}},{f_{s}}(\alpha({x_{i}});{w_{s}})}\right)}, (3)
Lksubscript𝐿𝑘\displaystyle L_{k} =1Nk​∑xi∈Dk𝟏max⁡(y¯i)≥τ​l​(arg⁡max⁡(y¯i),fk​(A​(xi);wk)),absent1subscript𝑁𝑘subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝐷𝑘subscript1subscript¯𝑦𝑖𝜏𝑙subscript¯𝑦𝑖subscript𝑓𝑘𝐴subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{1}{N_{k}}\sum\limits_{x_{i}\in D_{k}}\mathbf{1}_{{\max({{\bar{y}}_{i}})\geq\tau}}l\left({\arg\max(\overline{y}_{i}),{f_{k}}(A({x_{i}});{w_{k}})}\right), (4)

where (1) Dssubscript𝐷𝑠D_{s} is the set of Nssubscript𝑁𝑠N_{s} labeled samples, (2) Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} is the set of Nksubscript𝑁𝑘N_{k} unlabeled samples owned by the k𝑘k-th user, (3) wssubscript𝑤𝑠w_{s} (wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k}) are the weights of server model fssubscript𝑓𝑠f_{s} (k𝑘k-th user model fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k}), (4) l​(⋅,⋅)𝑙⋅⋅l(\cdot,\cdot) is the cross-entropy loss, α​(⋅)𝛼⋅\alpha(\cdot) and A​(⋅)𝐴⋅A(\cdot) are two data augmentation functions which we will soon describe in Remark 1, (5) y¯i=fk​(α​(xi);wk)subscript¯𝑦𝑖subscript𝑓𝑘𝛼subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘{{\bar{y}}_{i}}=f_{k}(\alpha(x_{i});w_{k}) is the prediction of the model fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} on the augmented sample α​(xi)𝛼subscript𝑥𝑖\alpha(x_{i}), (6) 𝟏1\bm{1} is the indicator function, (7) and τ𝜏\tau is the threshold hyperparameter which helps decide which samples have high confidence to be trained, i.e., the term 𝟏max⁡(y¯i)≥τsubscript1subscript¯𝑦𝑖𝜏\mathbf{1}_{\max(\bar{y}_{i})\geq\tau}. We refer to training with Eq. 3 and Eq. 4 as the CRL training objective.

Remark 1 (Data augmentation).

We now discuss the data augmentations in Eq. 3 and Eq. 4. In [11], the authors use two different types of data augmentations (DA): the standard flip-and-shift augmentation α​(⋅)𝛼⋅\alpha(\cdot) (referred to as weak DA); and the RandAugment [22] A​(⋅)𝐴⋅{A}(\cdot) (referred to as strong DA). Here, the latter RandAugment uses two different augmentation methods (i.e., shift and crop) out of twelve possible augmentation methods (e.g., rotate, shift, solarize, etc.) for one image. We refer the interested readers to [22] for a detailed explanation. The key idea behind using two DAs (i.e., weak DA and strong DA) is that the predictions of the same image with two data augmentations should be similar to each other. Recall that, on the user side, the data have no labels. Therefore, using this approach, we can use the pseudo-labels generated from weak DA samples to supervise strong DA samples, which is the loss between arg⁡max⁡(y¯i)subscript¯𝑦𝑖\arg\max(\overline{y}_{i}) and fk​(A​(xi);wk)subscript𝑓𝑘𝐴subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘{f_{k}}(A({x_{i}});{w_{k}}) in Eq. 4. This is shown in [11] to boost the testing performance.

Other training objectives. To study the CRL training objective, we compare it to two other training objectives. One uses classical self-training similar to the way defined in [23], which is also called “pseudo-labeling” in  [11]:

Lk=1Nk​∑xi∈Dksubscript𝐿𝑘1subscript𝑁𝑘subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝐷𝑘\displaystyle L_{k}=\frac{1}{N_{k}}\sum\limits_{x_{i}\in D_{k}} 𝟏max⁡(y¯i)≥τ​l​(arg⁡max⁡(y¯i),fk​(α​(xi);wk)).subscript1subscript¯𝑦𝑖𝜏𝑙subscript¯𝑦𝑖subscript𝑓𝑘𝛼subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘\displaystyle{\bf{1}}_{\max({{\bar{y}}_{i}})\geq\tau}l\left({\arg\max(\bar{y}_{i}),{f_{k}}(\alpha({x_{i}});{w_{k}})}\right). (5)

This loss can be explained as replacing two augmentations α​(⋅)𝛼⋅\alpha(\cdot) and A​(⋅)𝐴⋅A(\cdot) in the CRL training objective Eq. 4 with a single standard flip-and-shift augmentation α​(⋅)𝛼⋅\alpha(\cdot). It is called self-training because the pseudo-labels obtained by applying arg⁡max\arg\max to the model’s output y¯i=fk​(α​(xi);wk)subscript¯𝑦𝑖subscript𝑓𝑘𝛼subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘{{\bar{y}}_{i}}=f_{k}(\alpha(x_{i});w_{k}) are used to supervise the model’s output fk​(α​(xi);wk)subscript𝑓𝑘𝛼subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘f_{k}(\alpha(x_{i});w_{k}) itself. We refer to Eq. 5 as the self-training objective.

The other training objective assumes that the users have (oracle) ground-truth labels, and it uses standard empirical risk minimization for the user loss, e.g., used in [2]:

Lksubscript𝐿𝑘\displaystyle L_{k} =1Nk​∑xi∈Dkl​(yi,fk​(α​(xi);wk)),absent1subscript𝑁𝑘subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝐷𝑘𝑙subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑓𝑘𝛼subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{1}{N_{k}}\sum\nolimits_{x_{i}\in D_{k}}l\left(y_{i},f_{k}(\alpha(x_{i});w_{k})\right), (6)

where yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is the (oracle) ground-truth label of xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}. We refer to Eq. 6 as the supervised training objective.

3.2 Design choice 2: normalization method

In this subsection, we describe the next design choice regarding the normalization method. Recent works [24, 25] find that in supervised FL with non-iid data distributions, the performance of group normalization (GN) is usually much better than that of batch normalization (BN). In contrast to BN, which normalizes the feature maps over the batch, height, and width dimensions, GN normalizes the feature maps over the channel, height, and width dimensions. We conjecture that the improvement of applying GN in FL is due to the reduced gradient diversity, and we thus empirically evaluate the effects of these two different normalization methods.

3.3 Design choice 3: model averaging

In this subsection, we study model averaging methods. We focus on a novel grouping-based averaging method. The main idea is to divide the C𝐶C communication users in each round into S>1𝑆1S>1 groups and then perform the average group-wise. Specifically, after collecting all C𝐶C model weights from the communication users, the server randomly divides them into S𝑆S equal-sized groups {Git}i=1Ssuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑡𝑖1𝑆\{G_{i}^{t}\}_{i=1}^{S}, and updates the averaged weights according to:

{wa​v​g,it+1=(wst+∑k∈Gitwkt)/(|Git|+1),∀i∈{1​…​S}wa​v​gt+1=∑i=1Swa​v​g,it+1/S.casesformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑖𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑠𝑡subscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑡1for-all𝑖1…𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑖𝑡1𝑆\small\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}w_{avg,i}^{t+1}=\left(w_{s}^{t}+\sum\nolimits_{k\in{G_{i}^{t}}}w_{k}^{t}\right)/(|G_{i}^{t}|+1),~{}\forall i\in\{1\ldots S\}\\ w_{avg}^{t+1}=\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{S}w_{avg,i}^{t+1}/S.\end{array}\right. (7)

In the equation above, wa​v​g,it+1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑖𝑡1w_{avg,i}^{t+1} represents the averaged weights in each group, and wa​v​gt+1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑡1w_{avg}^{t+1} is the average of these averaged weights. After computing wa​v​g,it+1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑖𝑡1w_{avg,i}^{t+1} and wa​v​gt+1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑡1w_{avg}^{t+1}, the server broadcasts wa​v​g,it+1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑖𝑡1w_{avg,i}^{t+1} to the user group Gitsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑡G_{i}^{t}, and it uses wa​v​gt+1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑡1w_{avg}^{t+1} for the training (updates) done by the server itself on the labeled data. It is worth noting that the groups {Git}i=1Ssuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑡𝑖1𝑆\{G_{i}^{t}\}_{i=1}^{S} change with t𝑡t because the set of participating users 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t} change with time. We compare the grouping-based averaging method to FedAvg:

wa​v​gt+1=F​e​d​A​v​g(wst+∑k∈𝒞twkt)/(C+1),superscript𝐹𝑒𝑑𝐴𝑣𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑠𝑡subscript𝑘subscript𝒞𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝐶1\small w_{avg}^{t+1}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle FedAvg}}{{=}}\left(w_{s}^{t}+\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{C}_{t}}w_{k}^{t}\right)/(C+1), (8)

where 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t} denotes the set of participating users with size C𝐶C in each round.

3.4 Comparing different SSFL methods

In this subsection, we study different design choices by studying five different methods:

  • •

    CRL with BN uses Eq. 3 and Eq. 4 as the training objective. It uses BN as the normalization method and FedAvg in Eq. 8 as the model averaging method.

  • •

    Self-training uses Eq. 5 as the training objective. It also uses BN and FedAvg.

  • •

    Supervised training uses Eq. 6 as the training objective. It also uses BN and FedAvg.

  • •

    CRL with GN uses Eq. 3 and Eq. 4 as the training objective. It replaces BN with GN, and it uses FedAvg.

  • •

    Grouping-based uses the same CRL training objective and GN, as in CRL with GN, but it uses the grouping-based averaging method in Eq. 7 instead of FedAvg.

We compare CRL with BN to self-training and supervised training to show where the CRL training objective stands compared to both semi-supervised and supervised algorithms. We compare CRL with BN to CRL with GN to show which normalization method is better. Further, we compare CRL with GN with the grouping-based method to show which model averaging method is better. The grouping-based solution combines CRL, GN, and our grouping-based averaging method. This solution is our main algorithm.

We use ResNet-18 [26] on Cifar-10. Here, for the environmental factors in § 2.3, we set T=16𝑇16T=16, K=10𝐾10K=10, C=10𝐶10C=10, and Ns=1000subscript𝑁𝑠1000N_{s}=1000. We compare under two R𝑅R values, with R=0.4𝑅0.4R=0.4 referred to as the non-iid case, and R=0𝑅0R=0 referred to as the iid case. The threshold τ𝜏\tau used in Eq. 3 and Eq. 4 is chosen to be 0.950.950.95, the same as in [11].

See Figure 2 for the results. From the test accuracy results, we have the following observations.

  • •

    When restricted to either the iid or the non-iid case, CRL improves significantly over self-training, but it cannot achieve the accuracy of supervised training.

  • •

    By comparing CRL with BN to CRL with GN, we show that GN improves the test accuracy.

  • •

    By comparing CRL with GN to the grouping-based method, we show that the grouping-based averaging improves the test accuracy compared to FedAvg.

3.5 Gradient diversity analysis of different methods.

In this subsection, we use the gradient diversity in Definition 1 to analyze different design choices. See Fig. 3 and Fig. 4. The left plot shows the convergence curves. The right plot shows the gradient diversity values. Then, we parse the results:

  • •

    When restricted to either the iid or the non-iid case, GN reduces gradient diversity compared to BN.

  • •

    Similarly, when restricted to either the iid or the non-iid case, grouping-based averaging reduces gradient diversity compared to FedAvg (see the comparison to CRL with GN, which uses FedAvg).

  • •

    The grouping-based method has a comparable gradient diversity value to supervised training.

4 Results under different factors

In this section, we extensively evaluate our grouping-based SSFL solution, i.e., CRL objective combined with GN and grouping-based model averaging. We vary the environmental factors mentioned in § 2.3, which include the non-iidness R𝑅R, the communication period T𝑇T, the number of labeled data Nssubscript𝑁𝑠N_{s} in the server, the user number K𝐾K and the number of participating users C𝐶C. All the environmental factors used in this section are reported in Tab. A.2.

Experiment settings. We consider three datasets, Cifar-10, SVHN, and EMNIST in our empirical evaluation. We use ResNet-18 as the training model on both Cifar-10 and SVHN datasets; and we use the same CNN model as [24] on EMNIST. See Appendix A for more details.

4.1 Impact of R𝑅R, T𝑇T, and Nssubscript𝑁𝑠N_{s}

In this subsection, we study the effect of the first three environmental factors. First, we illustrate the effect of the non-iid level R𝑅R (defined in Definition 2). For Cifar-10, SVHN and EMNIST, the experiment parameters are reported respectively in rows 1-3 of Tab. A.2. For each experiment, we fix all the parameters only except the non-iidness parameter R𝑅R. The results are shown in the left of Fig. 5. When R=0𝑅0R=0, each user has the same empirical class distribution which is uniform. When R=1𝑅1R=1, each user only has a single class of data. As can be seen, the accuracy decreases as the non-iid level R𝑅R increases (from 93.42% to 81.7% on Cifar-10, from 95.32% to 92.49% on SVHN, and from 84.43% to 82.69% on EMNIST.) This is in accord with our intuition that iid data distribution typically leads to the best result.

We also illustrate the effect of the communication period T𝑇T on Cifar-10, SVHN, and EMNIST. For these three datasets, the experiment parameters are reported in rows 4-6 of Tab. A.2. In these experiments, we again only vary the communication period T𝑇T while holding all the remaining parameters fixed. The middle of Fig. 5 presents our results. Increasing T𝑇T (i.e., communicating less frequently) leads to a worse generalization performance. This is explainable since the local model can overfit when T𝑇T is large. In addition, the convergence behaviors on Cifar-10 at different T𝑇T can be found in Fig. B.1.

Then, we investigate the impact of the number of labeled samples Nssubscript𝑁𝑠N_{s} in the server. For the experiments on three datasets, the experiment parameters are shown in rows 7-9 of Tab. A.2. The results are shown in the right part of Fig. 5. We notice that increasing the amount of labeled data in the server can improve the final generalization performance. For example, with 5000 labeled samples, the test accuracy values on all the three datasets are higher as compared to 1000 labeled data, e.g., for Cifar-10 the improvement is 1.92%, for SVHN the improvement is 0.66%, and for EMNIST the improvement is 2.07%. These results are reasonable since the increase in the amount of labeled data can make the model trained by the server more accurate, which helps the users obtain more accurate pseudo-labels. In the extreme case where the server has the entire labeled training dataset, the situation degrades to a supervised learning setting.

4.2 Impact of C𝐶C and K𝐾K, and the effectiveness of grouping-based average when C𝐶C is large

In this subsection, we analyze the remaining two environmental factors C𝐶C and K𝐾K. Again, we change one specific environmental factor while holding all the other factors fixed. The settings of the environmental factors for the experiments in this subsection are reported in rows 10-18 of Tab. A.2.

The results of Cifar-10 and SVHN are shown in Tab. 1, and the result of EMNIST is presented in Tab. 2. On the top of Tab. 1, we set C=K𝐶𝐾C=K and increase K𝐾K. At the bottom of Tab. 1, we show the result with fixed C=10𝐶10C=10 and various K𝐾K (from 10 to 30).

As can be seen from the top of Tab. 1, increasing the number of users K𝐾K has a marginal effect (<<1%) on the accuracy, from K=10𝐾10K=10 to K=30𝐾30K=30. One notable thing here is that with K=30𝐾30K=30, if we train 40 epochs on SVHN, the accuracy is 78.77%, which is 16.72% lower than K=10𝐾10K=10. If we increase the training epochs from 40 to 120 for K=30𝐾30K=30 on SVHN, the final accuracy is 94.93%. One can refer to Fig. C.1 for the convergence curve of this experiment.

Counterintuitively, when comparing the results at the bottom of Tab. 1 to the results on the top, the results when C<K𝐶𝐾C<K are consistently better than when C=K𝐶𝐾C=K. Particularly, the K=30𝐾30K=30, C=10𝐶10C=10 case outperforms C=30𝐶30C=30 by 0.72% on Cifar-10 and by 14.79% on SVHN, respectively.

Similar to the above results of Cifar-10 and SVHN, from the results of EMNIST shown in Tab. 2, one can clearly see that when K𝐾K is large, a large C𝐶C decreases the performance significantly if one does not use the grouping-based average. Particularly, the K=C=47𝐾𝐶47K=C=47 case is lower than C=10𝐶10C=10 by 17.59%. However, this reduction in accuracy can be mitigated if we use the grouping-based method, which is only 1.48%.

We proceed to study why the grouping-based averaging performs significantly better than FedAvg for the particular case when C𝐶C is large. See Fig. 6. From the results, we can see that the large number of communicating users causes large gradient diversity. We can also see that grouping-based averaging can reduce gradient diversity and increase accuracy. See appendix § D for additional analysis on gradient diversity. We also conduct additional experiments to study the user participation rate C/K𝐶𝐾C/K in § E.

4.3 Comparing with other supervised/semi-supervised results

In this subsection, we compare our grouping-based method with other FL algorithms, in both semi-supervised and supervised settings. First, in the semi-supervised setting, we conduct the experiment on Cifar-10 with exactly the same setting as a recent SSFL paper [9]. For the Cifar-10 data, according to Table 1 in [9], we set Ns=5000subscript𝑁𝑠5000N_{s}=5000, K=100𝐾100K=100, C=5𝐶5C=5, and R=0𝑅0R=0 (which is the iid case) or R=1𝑅1R=1 (which is the most difficult non-iid case). From Tab. 3, one can see that our grouping-based solution outperforms the method proposed in [9] by a large margin. We notice that the results in [9] are presented in two different settings including the labels-at-server setting and the labels-at-client setting. The first setting is the same as our paper, i.e., only the server has labeled data, while the users have unlabeled data. In this setting, Ns=5000subscript𝑁𝑠5000N_{s}=5000 labeled data are own by the server. The second setting is different but it is straightforward to apply our grouping-based solution. In this setting, Ns=5000subscript𝑁𝑠5000N_{s}=5000 labeled data are distributed to 100 users. In each round, C=5𝐶5C=5 users are random selected to communicate with the server. See Appendix H for the details of adapting our solution to the label-at-the-client setting.

We also compare our solution with supervised FL methods in Tab. 4. We choose two supervised FL methods for comparison: Supervised FedAvg [2] and DataSharing [16]. We set K=10𝐾10K=10, C=10𝐶10C=10 and T=32𝑇32T=32, and we use ResNet-18 to be the model for training. The non-iid setting of DataSharing [16] corresponds to the scenario where we set R=0.29𝑅0.29R=0.29. For our solutions, we set Ns=1000subscript𝑁𝑠1000N_{s}=1000 and R=0.4𝑅0.4R=0.4. The detailed experimental parameters of different methods can be seen from rows 22-25 of Tab. A.2. Larger R𝑅R means a higher non-iid level and thus a more difficult scenario (which we have experimentally demonstrated in Fig. 5). From Tab. 4 we see that the performance of our method (R=0.4𝑅0.4R=0.4) on Cifar-10 is still better than Supervised FedAvg (R=0.29𝑅0.29R=0.29) and DataSharing methods (R=0.29𝑅0.29R=0.29) even when the scenario of R=0.4𝑅0.4R=0.4 is more difficult.

We also compare our method with EASGD [14] and OverlapSGD [15] which are communication efficient algorithms under supervised settings. We use the same parameters in their papers, i.e., K=16𝐾16K=16, R=0.4𝑅0.4R=0.4, C=16𝐶16C=16 and Ns=1000subscript𝑁𝑠1000N_{s}=1000 on Cifar-10. See rows 26-29 of Tab. A.2 for the details. The results are shown in Tab. 5. We see that our result has better accuracy than both EASGD and OverlapSGD. Particularly, even with T=32𝑇32T=32 (larger T𝑇T means a harder scenario; see Fig. 5), our method has 0.80% or 0.29% better performance, as compared to EASGD or OverlapSGD in the setting of T=2𝑇2T=2, respectively. Note that both EASGD and OverlapSGD are supervised algorithms, which means they have all the data labels.

There are other important issues we consider. For example, we evaluate the performance of our grouping-based method in fully supervised FL in § F, and we show that the improvement in this scenario is limited. Thus, our method is more suitable in the SSFL setting. We also compare our grouping-based solution with FixMatch [11] in § G). We show that our results are comparable to FixMatch even if FixMatch uses centralized setting. Moreover, we extend our current methods to the setting where users can have both labeled and unlabeled samples in § H, i.e., the labels-at-client case. We also provide additional results on another semi-supervised dataset STL-10, see § I. Finally, since for federated learning, we are interested in studying what happens when the number of users is large, we provide an additional experiment with the number of users set to 470 in § J. We show that the grouping-based method outperforms FedAvg in this setting as well.

5 Related work

Federated learning. Federated learning (FL) [1, 2, 4, 27, 16, 28, 29, 30, 18, 31] is a decentralized computing framework that enables multiple users to learn a shared model while potentially protecting the privacy of users (although recent work [32] shows this may not be the case). Federated Averaging (FedAvg) [2], which is the most popular FL algorithm, shows good performance when the data distribution across users is iid. However, in the non-iid case, the performance can significantly degrade. In fact, dealing with non-iid distributions is deemed by many to be one of the most critical challenges in FL [16, 28, 33]. In [16], a data-sharing method is proposed to improve the final accuracy. However, sharing massive data among all users requires both large storage space as well as stable connections between users and the server. Importantly, all of these methods require the data stored by the local users to come with ground-truth labels (in order to perform model updates locally). The FL problem in the semi-supervised setting, when users do not have labels, however, is “relatively ignored” and has “little prior arts,” as mentioned in a recent survey paper [4].

In addition to the challenge of the non-iidness of the data distribution and the need for local ground truth labels, communication efficiency is another critical problem in FL [30, 34, 35, 36, 37]. One way to relieve the communication burden of FL is to increase the period (the number of local gradient descent iterations) between consecutive communication stages. However, when this communication period increases, the diversity between different models increases, and the fusion of these models by the server may lead to accuracy degradation. To handle this problem, [35] proposes FedProx, which adds a proximal term in the user local loss function to restrict the update distance between the local model and the global model. Other work considers gradient compression and model compression to reduce the communication cost [30, 31, 37]. For example, [30] proposes atomic sparsification of stochastic gradients, which leads to significantly faster distributed training.

Semi-supervised Learning. Semi-supervised learning (SSL) is a classical problem when only a small fraction of data is labeled [38, 11, 23, 39, 40, 41, 42, 43]. SSL includes many impactful algorithms. For example, self-training [44] uses the model’s own predictions on unlabeled data to supervise the training of the same model. Co-training [45] trains two models in parallel using two set of conditionally independent features, and let the two models supervise each other. Tritraining [39] first trains three classifiers using bootstrap. Then, each classifier is trained on samples agreed by the other two classifiers. Graph-based SSL [46] propagates labels on a graph generated by the similarity between different samples.

In recent years, the problem of SSL in the context of deep neural networks has been extensively studied. In [42], a specific consistency regularization is used: the average predictions on several augmented views of a single unlabeled sample is sharpened (using temperature scaling) and used to supervise the different predictions. Mixup [47] is further applied as a traditional regularization approach. Unsupervised data augmentation (UDA) [48] applies AutoAugment [49] to generate data-dependent augmentations to improve the performance. In [23], a self-training method is introduced, which improves the state-of-the-art accuracy on ImageNet [50], even compared to supervised learning [26, 51]. In [11], a simplified SSL loss is proposed which directly uses pseudo-labeling to provide consistency regularization on augmented samples.

SSFL. Regarding the motivation of SSFL, a recent survey paper [4] raises the practical concern that users may not have ground-truth labels. Regarding the problem formulation, [9] is the most relevant. It uses a consistency loss to achieve the agreement between users, which aligns with the intuition in our method to reduce gradient diversity. The setting of [27] is also similar to ours but focuses on the label-at-client scenario. Apart from these two, there are several other contemporary papers that consider different settings. For example, the paper [52] considers using shared unlabeled data for distillation-based message exchanging. The paper [18] assumes that the unlabeled data is held by the server. The paper [53] focuses on the “vertical” FL setting in which the data is partitioned from the feature dimension. Two other papers [54, 55] use SSFL in specific professional fields. Another paper [56] studies semi-supervised private aggregation of an ensemble of teacher models trained on separate subsets of the whole dataset, which is not in the FL setting but is closely related.

6 Conclusions

We studied the semi-supervised federated learning (SSFL) setting in which most samples are unlabeled. Based on the observations of large gradient diversity, we proposed to use GN and a novel grouping-based model averaging method. We conducted extensive evaluations in various scenarios to evaluate our solution. The results showed that our SSFL method achieves better test accuracy even when compared to existing semi-supervised or supervised FL algorithms.

We emphasize that our solution can be extended to other FL scenarios, such as standard supervised FL (see § F) and the label-at-client FL [4] (see § H). Another challenging scenario worth mentioning is where there is a significant mismatch between the user data distributions and the distribution at the server, in which case the label supervision from the server may conflict with the information provided by users. We envision that techniques from unsupervised domain adaptation [57] are useful to address this problem. In addition, personalization [58, 59] is important for SSFL because it can mitigate the mismatch between the data distributions at the server and at the users’ side. Although our work focuses on empirical analysis, it is meaningful future work to explore the theory behind the new SSFL setting, e.g., by advancing recent theoretical results in non-iid FL [60, 16] and combining with analysis of particular data augmentation schemes such as CRL.

Appendix

Appendix A Additional details on our empirical evaluation.

A.1 Datasets

Cifar-10 [61] consists of images with 3 channels, each of size 32×\times32 pixels. Each pixel is represented by an unsigned int8. This dataset consists of 60000 color images from 10 classes, with 6000 images in each class. There are 50000 training images and 10000 test images. SVHN [62] is obtained from images of house numbers in Google Street View images. It has 99289 digits from 10 classes. There are 73257 digits for training and 26032 digits for testing. All digits have been resized to a fixed resolution of 32×\times32 pixels. EMNIST [63] is a set of handwritten digits which have been resized to a fixed resolution of 28×\times28 pixels. It is an unbalanced dataset that has 814255 digits from 62 classes, including A-Z, a-z, and 0-9. However, since the uppercase and lowercase of some handwritten letters are difficult to distinguish, for these letters, following [63], we combine the uppercase and lowercase classes into a new class. There are 15 merged letters in total, including [C, I, J, K, L, M, O, P, S, U, V, W, X, Y, Z]. Thus, there are 47 classes left. To ensure every user has almost the same amount of data, following [63], we truncate the training dataset to have 2400 data points per class and drop the rest. Notice that the above pre-processing step to truncate the dataset and the letter-merging step are both used in [63] to improve the generalization accuracy. In particular, there are 112800 digits for training, and we use the full test dataset (18800 digits) for testing.

A.2 Data assignment procedures for a particular value of R𝑅R

For a dataset with d𝑑d classes, to synthesize a data assignment procedure such that the non-iid level is R𝑅R (see Definition 2), we follow the procedures below to distribute the data.

  1. 1.

    (Server data) We assign Nssubscript𝑁𝑠N_{s} labeled training samples from each of the d𝑑d classes to the server. Recall that Nssubscript𝑁𝑠N_{s} is the total number of samples at the server. Thus, the class distribution at the server is uniform.555Note that this step requires each class to have more than Ns/dsubscript𝑁𝑠𝑑N_{s}/d samples, which is satisfied in all of our experiments.

  2. 2.

    (User data) Let njsubscript𝑛𝑗n_{j} denote the number of samples left in class j𝑗j after distributing the data to the server. The empirical distribution across different classes for the remaining data is Q=[q1,…,qd]𝑄subscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞𝑑Q=[q_{1},\dots,q_{d}] such that ∑j=1dqj=1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑞𝑗1\sum_{j=1}^{d}q_{j}=1, where qi=ni∑j=1dnjsubscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑛𝑗q_{i}=\frac{n_{i}}{\sum_{j=1}^{d}n_{j}}. For a specific data assignment to the users, we use the main class of a user to refer to the class with the maximum number of samples at the user. Let mjsubscript𝑚𝑗m_{j} denote the number of users whose main class is j𝑗j, and let 𝒰j={Userj​1,Userj​2,…,Userj​mj\mathcal{U}_{j}=\{\text{User}_{j1},\text{User}_{j2},\dots,\text{User}_{jm_{j}}} denote the set of such users. The mjsubscript𝑚𝑗m_{j}’s should be chosen to satisfy the constraint ∑j=1dmj=Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑚𝑗𝐾\sum_{j=1}^{d}m_{j}=K in which K𝐾K is the total number of users and d𝑑d is the number of classes.

    We use Userj​1∈𝒰jsubscriptUser𝑗1subscript𝒰𝑗\text{User}_{j1}\in\mathcal{U}_{j} as an example to illustrate the data assignment (the same for other users):

    1. (a)

      We first assign nj​R/mjsubscript𝑛𝑗𝑅subscript𝑚𝑗n_{j}R/m_{j} unlabeled training samples for the main class j𝑗j.

    2. (b)

      After that, for each class i∈{1,…,d}𝑖1…𝑑i\in\{1,\dots,d\}, we assign (1−R)​ni​qj/mj1𝑅subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑞𝑗subscript𝑚𝑗(1-R)n_{i}q_{j}/m_{j} unlabeled samples, in which i𝑖i can be equal to the main class j𝑗j.

According to the above data assignment procedures, for a user who belongs to 𝒰jsubscript𝒰𝑗\mathcal{U}_{j}(e.g., Userj​1subscriptUser𝑗1\text{User}_{j1}), the number of unlabeled data for each class i𝑖i is:

Nj,i={ni​R/mj+ni​qj​(1−R)/mj,for ​i=jni​qj​(1−R)/mj,for ​i≠j.subscript𝑁𝑗𝑖casessubscript𝑛𝑖𝑅subscript𝑚𝑗subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑞𝑗1𝑅subscript𝑚𝑗for 𝑖𝑗subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑞𝑗1𝑅subscript𝑚𝑗for 𝑖𝑗N_{j,i}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}{n_{i}}R/{m_{j}}+{n_{i}}{q_{j}}(1-R)/{m_{j}},~{}~{}\text{for }i=j\\ {n_{i}}{q_{j}}(1-R)/{m_{j}},~{}~{}\text{for }i\neq j.\end{array}\right. (9)

The total number of unlabeled data held by this user is ∑i=1dNj,i=nj/mjsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝑁𝑗𝑖subscript𝑛𝑗subscript𝑚𝑗\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{d}{{N_{j,i}}}={n_{j}}/m_{j}. The empirical distribution Pj=[qj,1,…,qj,d]subscript𝑃𝑗subscript𝑞𝑗1…subscript𝑞𝑗𝑑P_{j}=[q_{j,1},\dots,q_{j,d}] across different classes can be calculated,

qj,i={R+qj​(1−R),for ​i=jqi​(1−R),for ​i≠j.subscript𝑞𝑗𝑖cases𝑅subscript𝑞𝑗1𝑅for 𝑖𝑗subscript𝑞𝑖1𝑅for 𝑖𝑗q_{j,i}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}R+{q_{j}}(1-R),~{}~{}\text{for }i=j\\ {q_{i}}(1-R),~{}~{}\text{for }i\neq j.\end{array}\right. (10)

One can see that, for the two users whose main classes are j𝑗j and k𝑘k (j≠k𝑗𝑘j\neq k), we have ‖Pj−Pk‖1=2​Rsubscriptnormsubscript𝑃𝑗subscript𝑃𝑘12𝑅{\left\|{{P_{j}}-{P_{k}}}\right\|_{1}}=2R. In this case, based on Definition 2, the total distance is R𝑅R.

A.3 Optimizer

For all our computations, the optimizer we use is SGD with momentum. For the learning rate schedule, we use the cosine learning rate decay [64], shown in the Eq. 11 below, which is a commonly used schedule in SSL [11]:

γt=γ×max{cos(π×c×t−e​M/BE​M/B−e​M/B,),ε},\small{\gamma_{t}}=\gamma\times\max\left\{{\cos\left({\pi\times c\times\frac{{t-eM/B}}{{EM/B-eM/B}}},\right),\varepsilon}\right\}, (11)

where γ𝛾\gamma is the base learning rate, c𝑐c is the periodic coefficient, E𝐸E is the number of training epochs, B𝐵B is the batch size, t𝑡t is the current iteration, M𝑀M is the number of training samples used in one epoch, e𝑒e is the number of epochs for warmup [65], and ε𝜀\varepsilon is a small constant. The hyperparameters used for different datasets can be found in Tab. A.1.

We believe that if one further tunes those hyperparameters, the performance of our grouping-based methods can improve further.

A.4 Computing infrastructure

All experiments use NVIDIA GPU servers as computing nodes. Each server contains 8 TITAN V GPUs and the servers are internetworked via commodity 1 Gbps Ethernet. In our experiments, we set the random seed to 2019 to partition the training data according to § A.2 across all nodes. The experiments are implemented in PyTorch and Gloo communication backend, and we generate the weights of the neural networks with random seed 1. Thus, we can simulate broadcasting the same initialized machine learning model to all participants, and the results are reproducible.

A.5 Experiment parameters

We include all the environmental parameters used in § 4. See Tab. A.2. We have defined these parameters in § 2.3. They include the non-iidness R𝑅R, the communication period T𝑇T, the number of labeled data Nssubscript𝑁𝑠N_{s} held by the server, the user number K𝐾K, the number of participating users C𝐶C, and the number of groups S𝑆S for our grouping-based method. We have also included the experiment title, the dataset used in the experiment, and the FL method that we test.

Appendix B Convergence speed of different communication period T𝑇T on Cifar-10

In this section, we show the test accuracy curves of training with different communication period T𝑇T on Cifar-10, which provides more details to the experimental results discussed in § 4.1. See Fig. B.1. The experimental settings are also presented in § 4.1. From Fig. B.1, we can see that when T𝑇T is small, our grouping based method, which combines the CRL training objective and GN, converges quickly.

Appendix C The effect of training epochs on SVHN

In this section, we study the effect of training epochs on SVHN when K=C=30𝐾𝐶30K=C=30, which provides more details to the experiments in Tab. 1, § 4.2. As shown in Tab. 1, the accuracy of our grouping-based method on SVHN with K=C=30𝐾𝐶30K=C=30 and E=40𝐸40E=40 is much lower than that of K=C=10𝐾𝐶10K=C=10 and E=40𝐸40E=40. Increasing the number of training epochs to E=120𝐸120E=120 can significantly improve the performance of K=C=30𝐾𝐶30K=C=30. The comparison is shown in Fig. C.1.

Appendix D Ablation study on gradient diversity

In this section, we provide more ablation study, by measuring gradient diversity with multiple alternative definitions. Recall that gradient diversity Eq. 1 measures the dissimilarity between concurrent gradient updates of different users. As we have discussed extensively in the main paper, reducing gradient diversity is the key to improving SSFL methods. Thus, we study gradient diversity by selecting several different ways to compute.

First, we can remove the square operation in Eq. 1, and we only use the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm to measure gradient diversity:

Δ1t​(w)=∑k∈𝒞t‖∇wkt‖2/‖∑k∈𝒞t∇wkt‖2.superscriptsubscriptΔ1𝑡𝑤subscript𝑘subscript𝒞𝑡subscriptnorm∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡2subscriptnormsubscript𝑘subscript𝒞𝑡∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡2\small\Delta_{1}^{t}(w)=\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{C}_{t}}{\left\|\nabla w_{k}^{t}\right\|_{2}}/\left\|\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{C}_{t}}\nabla w_{k}^{t}\right\|_{2}. (12)

Second, we can also replace the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm with the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm, which leads to the following two alternatives with/without the square operation:

Δ2t​(w)=∑k∈𝒞t‖∇wkt‖12/‖∑k∈𝒞t∇wkt‖12.superscriptsubscriptΔ2𝑡𝑤subscript𝑘subscript𝒞𝑡superscriptsubscriptnorm∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡12superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑘subscript𝒞𝑡∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡12\small\Delta_{2}^{t}(w)=\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{C}_{t}}{\left\|\nabla w_{k}^{t}\right\|_{1}^{2}}/\left\|\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{C}_{t}}\nabla w_{k}^{t}\right\|_{1}^{2}. (13)
Δ3t​(w)=∑k∈𝒞t‖∇wkt‖1/‖∑k∈𝒞t∇wkt‖1.superscriptsubscriptΔ3𝑡𝑤subscript𝑘subscript𝒞𝑡subscriptnorm∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1subscriptnormsubscript𝑘subscript𝒞𝑡∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1\small\Delta_{3}^{t}(w)=\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{C}_{t}}{\left\|\nabla w_{k}^{t}\right\|_{1}}/\left\|\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{C}_{t}}\nabla w_{k}^{t}\right\|_{1}. (14)

Third, we can change the set 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t} in the computation. Note that in all of the definitions above, we calculated gradient diversity only using the gradients from the users. Therefore, the set 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t} only contains users. However, we can also include the server gradient in the calculation of gradient diversity.

Fourth, we can change the way of computing each individual gradient. We notice that in FL, the local gradient updates are not aggregated directly. Instead, sequential gradient updates are applied to each user. Then, the updated weights from the users are averaged. Thus, instead of calculating the diversity of gradient ∇wkt∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡\nabla w_{k}^{t} evaluated on all the user data, we can define ∇wkt∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡\nabla w_{k}^{t} as the difference between the model before and after local gradient updates, i.e.

∇wkt={wkt−wa​v​gt−1,for​FedAvg,wkt−wa​v​g,it−1,for​grouping-based,∇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡casessuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑡1forFedAvgsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑖𝑡1forgrouping-based\nabla w_{k}^{t}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}w_{k}^{t}-w_{avg}^{t-1},\rm{for\ FedAvg,}\\ w_{k}^{t}-w_{avg,i}^{t-1},\rm{for\ \text{grouping-based}},\end{array}\right. (15)

where i𝑖i is the index of group to which user k𝑘k belongs; see Eq. 7. It can be seen that Eq. 15 is the cumulative change in weights after the local gradient updates. We can substitute the above-defined gradient Eq. 15 into Eq. 1 and Eq. 12-Eq. 14 to calculate gradient diversity.

Thus, we can either perform the square operation or not, either use the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm or the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm, either include the server or not in 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t}, and either using the cumulative gradient updates Eq. 15 or not. In total, we have 2×2×2×2=162222162\times 2\times 2\times 2=16 different ways of measuring gradient diversity.

Therefore, we perform all the 16 different ways of calculating gradient diversity, and repeat the comparison between FedAvg and the grouping-based method under the same setting of the experiments on EMNIST shown in § 4.2. The results are reported in Fig. D.1 - Fig. D.4.

We can see that the gradient diversity values of the grouping-based averaging method are consistently lower than FedAvg, and the corresponding test accuracy values are consistently higher than FedAvg. More interestingly, we see that the grouping-based averaging method significantly accelerates the convergence speed compared to FedAvg. In other words, from Fig. D.1 - Fig. D.4, a large gradient diversity value across different users can slow down the training process significantly.

Appendix E Impact of the ratio η=C/K𝜂𝐶𝐾\eta=C/K

In this section, we study the impact of the user connection ratio because in real-life FL scenarios, the number of connected users can vary during training. Here, we define the ratio of the connected users as η=C/K𝜂𝐶𝐾\eta=C/K, and we study the impact of η𝜂\eta on Cifar-10 and SVHN.

We set T=16𝑇16T=16, R=0.4𝑅0.4R=0.4, and Ns=1000subscript𝑁𝑠1000N_{s}=1000 for both Cifar-10 and SVHN. We use ResNet-18 [26] as the model for training, and we train 300 epochs and 40 epochs respectively on Cifar-10 and SVHN. The experiment parameters are shown in rows 30-31 of Tab. A.2. The results of our grouping-based method on Cifar-10 and SVHN are shown in Tab. E.1. It can be found that as η𝜂\eta increases from 110110\frac{1}{10} to 1313\frac{1}{3}, the performance of our grouping-based method gradually improves. This result is intuitive since a smaller η𝜂\eta means fewer models participate in the model averaging, and only a small ratio of the models can be utilized. It should also be noted that, as shown in § 4.2, when η𝜂\eta increases to a large value (e.g. η=1𝜂1\eta=1), the diversity of models across users becomes too large, and the performance decreases. Therefore, properly increasing η𝜂\eta can improve the performance but increasing η𝜂\eta too much can also decrease the performance. However, more work is needed to determine the most effective ratios for different datasets.

Appendix F Grouping-based averaging in fully supervised FL

In this section, we study whether the grouping-based averaging can be extended to supervised FL (SFL). We want to see whether this particular way of averaging is more suitable for the semi-supervised setup or the supervised setup. We conduct experiments on EMNIST using SFL with three different settings with different number of users K∈{47,20,10}𝐾472010K\in\{47,20,10\}. In these three settings, we let C=K𝐶𝐾C=K. The other environmental factors are shown in rows 32-34 of Tab. A.2. We set the group number S=5𝑆5S=5, S=2𝑆2S=2 and S=2𝑆2S=2 for the setting of K=47𝐾47K=47, K=20𝐾20K=20 and K=10𝐾10K=10, respectively. See Table F.1. The results show that the performance of the grouping method is only slightly better than that of FedAvg. Thus, the performance gain of the grouping-based averaging method for SFL is much less than that of SSFL. This mean that grouping-based averaging is more suitable for the semi-supervised setup than the supervised setup.

Appendix G Comparison of grouping-based solution and a centralized scheme

In this section, we compare our grouping-based solution, which works in a distributed setting, to FixMatch [11] which is originally proposed for the centralized semi-supervised setting. In particular, we compare our method in the SSFL setting (T=16𝑇16T=16, R=0.4𝑅0.4R=0.4) and FixMatch (with centralized training on a single machine, T=1𝑇1T=1, R=0𝑅0R=0). For Cifar-10/SVHN/EMNIST, the environmental factors for both our grouping-based solution and FixMatch are shown in rows 35-40 of Tab. A.2. From Tab. G.1, we see that the results are comparable to FixMatch even if FixMatch uses centralized training.

Appendix H SSFL for the label-at-client scenario

In this section, we discuss a different scenario of SSFL when users have both unlabeled data and limited labeled data. Although in this paper, we have mainly focused on the case when labeled data is held by the server, we also think it is reasonable to assume the users have both unlabeled data and limited labeled data. Thus, in this section, we study this “label-at-client” case. Note that in this case, the server does not have any data, and only aggregates model weights. This different scenario is reasonable when users have access to interactive applications to provide labels to the local data [7].

All of our solutions discussed in the main paper apply directly to this different scenario. More specifically, we can simply apply the same server loss function Eq. 3 to the labeled data at the users.

Now, we conduct an experiment on EMNIST to test the grouping-based solution, and the experiment results on Cifar-10 can been seen from Tab. 3. Here, we set K=C=47𝐾𝐶47K=C=47, T=16𝑇16T=16 and Ns=4700subscript𝑁𝑠4700N_{s}=4700, which has the same environmental factors as reported in Tab. 2 for the the grouping-based solution. See Tab. H.1 for the results. From the results, we see that for R=0.4𝑅0.4R=0.4, the obtained accuracy 81.88%percent81.8881.88\%. This result indicates that our method can still apply to this alternative setting where users have both labeled and unlabeled data.

Appendix I Performance on STL-10

In this section, we test all of our solutions on STL-10 [66], which is a dataset created specifically for semi-supervised learning. One thing worth noting is that we can only test the iid setting (R=0𝑅0R=0) on STL-10. This is because for the non-iid setting, we need to synthesize datasets with a particular non-iid level R𝑅R, but STL-10 does not have full labeling information for us to synthesize the data distribution procedure (see § A.2). For STL-10, we set K=10𝐾10K=10, C=2𝐶2C=2, T=16𝑇16T=16 and Ns=1000subscript𝑁𝑠1000N_{s}=1000. We use VGG11 as our model. The results are shown in Tab. I.1. The self-training solution achieves 74.25%. The CRL with BN uses Eq. 4 and Eq. 3, which is introduced in Section 3.1, achieves 78.96%. Then, when we change BN to GN, we achieve 81.71%. When we further change FedAvg to grouping-based averaging, we achieve 82.81%.

Appendix J Performance on EMNIST with a large user number

In this section, we study the performance of the FedAvg solution and the grouping-based averaging with a large user number, to see if this particular way of averaging is still useful when the number of users is particularly large (which is closer to the practical scenario). We conduct experiments on EMNIST with K=470𝐾470K=470, C={10,20,30}𝐶102030C=\{10,20,30\} and the number of groups S=2𝑆2S=2. We notice that this result represents the case when we have a relatively small user connection ratio η=C/K𝜂𝐶𝐾\eta=C/K.

The results in Table J.1 show that the performance of the grouping-based averaging is better than that of FedAvg even with 470 users. One can also observe that as the number of communicating users C𝐶C increases, the performance of the FedAvg decreases, which is consistent with the experimental phenomenon observed in § 4.2.
